Welcome to Professional Competencies

Please begin this module by reviewing the module handbook. You will find additional information such as the weekly schedule, learning methods, and essential resources. Students are responsible for reading the content of this document. For further information, contact your instructor

View module handbook

Module Outline

This pathway module will introduce students to a range of professional, personal, and study skills across various types of learning activities including lectures, group workshops, collaborative research projects, online formative assessments, and discussions.

By completing this module, you will acquire practical art and design knowledge, enhancing your ability to explore personal ideas and Students are required to review their lecture notes and undertake preparatory reading and research on assigned material in order to participate in class discussions individually and as part of a group.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

.

Use techniques for study, analysis, and reflection at university and elsewhere.

.

Work collaboratively within groups and teams and develop personal relationships.

.

Apply techniques to manage time, deadlines, and stress effectively.

.

Demonstrate knowledge of career planning, development, and employability.

Assessments

  • WEEKLY QUIZ: A series of 5 quizzes will be held each week and worth 15%25 of the overall grade

  • GROUP ASSIGNMENT: Group Presentation is worth 25%25 of the total grade

Assessment dates

Please note and manage your submission dates, they are important, and you must submit your assessments before the deadline. It is NOT possible to request an extension. The University will NOT send reminders if your submission is late or if you do not submit at all. If there are exceptional circumstances outside your control (for example, serious illness) affecting your ability to submit on time, you can download an Exceptional Circumstances (EC) formLinks to an external site..

Module Leader

.

Module Leader: Sandra Schneiderman

Sandra Schneiderman

Ms. Sandra is Student Affairs Team Leader as well as a Teacher. She is the liaison between faculty and students to develop effective lessons and individual learning plans. Ms. Sandra got her Bachelor of Education and Master of Education at the University of Melbourne. In addition, she also holds a Postgraduate Diploma in Gifted Education (Monash University) and Reading; Literature (University of Melbourne). From 2014-2020, she taught the International Baccalaureate Program at the United Nations International School (Vietnam). Her curriculum utilizes Case Study and Active Learning methods, and masterfully combines multimedia social technology classroom instruction across all aspects of the continuous and summative learning process.

week1.body:
Welcome to week 1

This first week aims to identify your learning style, to know yourself and your neighbours a bit better. At the end of the week, you should be able to create your future goals, write an email skilfully and give constructive feedback.

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. Prework: Read Chapter 11 of the course textbook - Career.

  2. Class 1: Intro to the module, identify your skills.

  3. Class 2: Write an email and give feedback

  4. Class 3: Your goals / Summative Canvas Quiz

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Lecture Slides: Review this week's lecture ppt.

  • Article 1: Understanding the Difference between Constructive Criticism and Criticism.

  • Article 2: 10 Examples of Constructive Feedback in the Workplace.

  • Article 3: 8 Examples of Constructive Feedback.

  • Article 4: Is the workforce ready for reinvention?

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard

week2.body:
Welcome to week 1

This week we will look at academic integrity. By the end of this lesson you should be able to define academic integrity, identify 5 criteria for evaluating source credibility, and understand what paraphrasing is.

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. prework: Read Part I of the course textbook. Essential features of academic writing

  2. Class 1: Lecture: After introducing ourselves, let's get started with academic integrity. We'll learn about what it is and how to avoid it, including websites to stay away from and what browsers you should use to conduct research.

  3. Class 2: Group workshop

  4. Class 3: Practical activity

  5. Class 4: Wrap up and Quiz

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Self-check: What is good academic conduct according to Staffordshire University?

  • Read: Find out when to paraphrase and when to summarise

  • Play: Defeat the plagiarism Goblins!

  • PPT: Review this week's lecture ppt

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard
